units.title: Cluster cells and assign annotations
units.text: We clustered cells at high resolution in each dataset and assigned cell annotations based on known marker gene expression and differential expression between clusters (Supplementary Table 2).
units.rationale: Describes the initial clustering and labeling of single‑cell data.

units.title: Assess data‑integration methods
units.text: To address batch effects and achieve a robust integration, we assessed 12 different data‑integration methods using the proportion of cell types in each organoid sample and compared the similarity of each cell type with counterparts in adult and fetal tissues.
units.rationale: Outlines the systematic evaluation of integration algorithms.

units.title: Select scPoli for embedding
units.text: We selected scPoli to generate an integrated embedding of all organoid cells, enabling a cohesive representation of the diverse data (Fig. 1e and Extended Data Fig. 1e).
units.rationale: Specifies the chosen method for creating a unified low‑dimensional representation.

units.title: Reannotate integrated atlas
units.text: The integrated atlas was reannotated based on the most frequent cell type in each cluster, resulting in 5 cell classes at level 1, 48 cell types at level 2 and 51 cell subtypes at level 3 (Fig. 1f–h).

units.title: Reintegrate and define cell type hierarchy
units.text: We reintegrated all cells and defined 5 cell types at level 1, 26 cell types at level 2 and 32 cell types at level 3 in the integrated atlas.
units.rationale: Provides a second round of integration to refine cell‑type granularity.

units.title: Perform pseudo‑bulk analysis
units.text: Pseudo‑bulk analysis using both raw and scPoli embedding on all organoid single‑cell datasets revealed stem cell source and tissue type as primary drivers of variance (Extended Data Fig. 4).
units.rationale: Summarizes a downstream quantitative comparison across samples.

units.title: Quantify cell‑type proportions per organoid sample
units.text: We quantified the proportion of cell types in each organoid sample and compared the similarity of each cell type with counterparts in adult and fetal tissues.
units.rationale: Measures how well organoid cell populations match reference tissues.

units.title: Generate hierarchical cell‑type annotation
units.text: We established a three‑level hierarchical cell‑type annotation: class (level 1), type (level 2) and subtype (level 3) (Fig. 2a,b).
units.rationale: Creates a structured framework for organizing cell identities.

units.title: Integrate organoid and primary tissue atlases
units.text: We integrated organoid cell types and states with primary adult and fetal tissue counterparts using neighborhood graph correlation24.
units.rationale: Describes the method for aligning organoid data to reference atlases.

units.title: Assess impact of stem‑cell source on similarity
units.text: Multiple regression analyses revealed that similarity to reference atlases was influenced by publication and stem cell source but not by scRNA‑seq methods, total sample counts or total sample genes.
units.rationale: Evaluates factors affecting concordance with reference datasets.
